entry.title: Plant Taxonomy
entry.content:
Introduction

Plants are classified into various categories based on their characteristics and evolutionary relationships. Understanding the taxonomy of a plant species involves familiarizing oneself with terms like family, genus, species, subspecies, variety, and cultivar.

Taxonomy

To explain plant taxonomy, let's look at the common houseplant Monstera deliciosa. The taxonomy of this plant may be represented using the following visualization.

  • Family Araceae

  • Genus Monstera

  • Species Monstera deliciosa subsp. douglasii

Let's explain what the different terms mean.

Family

A family in plant taxonomy represents a higher-level grouping that includes multiple genera sharing certain common traits. For instance, the Araceae family encompasses various genera such as Anthurium, Monstera and Philodendron.

Genus

A genus is a level below the family and groups together species that are closely related.

Species

A species is the basic unit of classification. It refers to a group of organisms that share similar characteristics and can interbreed to produce fertile offspring. Scientific names of species are composed of two words: the genus name ( italicized) followed by the species name (not italicized).

Epithet

epithet

Subspecies

Subspecies, positioned between a species and a variety, denotes a geographically isolated plant within a species. This isolation prevents interbreeding despite genetic compatibility. This geographical distinction often results in varied physical traits.

The notation "subsp." appears between the species and subspecies names.

  • Species Monstera adansonii subsp. laniata

As an example, for Monstera adansonii let's look at the geographical distributions of the subspecies adansonii and blanchetii.

As you can see, these subspecies are geographically isolated, allowing them to develop unique attributes.

Variety

A variety denotes a naturally occurring variation within a species. It is indicated by abbreviating "var." before the variety name, which is not italicized. For instance, Rosa indica var. odorata represents a variety of the garden rose with a distinct scent.

  • Species Monstera deliciosa var. douglasii

Cultivar

A cultivar is a cultivated variety developed through selective breeding or other human interventions. It can be seen as a variety produced by human selection and breeding rather than naturally occurring.

Cultivar names are capitalized and enclosed in single quotes but are not italicized. For example, 'Peace' is a cultivar of the garden rose.

Understanding these taxonomic terms helps scientists, horticulturists, and enthusiasts communicate precisely about plant species, their relationships, and their variations.

Common names

Each plant species has a scientific name. Often, the plant will also have common names. These are names that people use to refer to the plant. For example, the species Pilea peperomioides is also called the pass-along plant. This common name refers to the fact that this plant is very easily propagated and passed along as a gift.

Not only species, but also genera and familiae may have common names. For example, the Araceae family is often referred to as the arum family or the aroids.

entry.title: Soil
entry.content:
Introduction

There are many choices to make when it comes to selecting soil for your plant. There are different soil characteristics that you should take into account that should match the preferences of the plant. Additionally, soil amendments can be added to the soil.

Soil characteristics

When choosing soil for your plant, these 4 characteristics come into play.

  • nutrient richness: plants need nutrients for growth
  • drainage/aeration: sufficient drainage prevents root rot and allows the roots to breathe
  • moisture retention: moisture needs to be sufficiently retained to allow the roots to take it in
  • acidity: certain plants prefer more/less acidic soil (lower or higher pH level respectively)

Amendments

A soil amendment is any material added to soil to improve its physical properties, such as water retention, permeability, water infiltration, drainage, aeration and structure.

Coarse sand

Description: Larger grained sand particles. Characteristics: Provides weight and structure, aids in drainage.

Sand

Description: Finer grained sand particles. Characteristics: Helps with aeration, drainage, and particle separation in soil. low water retention

Loam

Description: Balanced soil texture containing sand, silt, and clay. Characteristics: Ideal soil texture, provides good drainage and moisture retention.

Shredded leaves

Description: Decomposed organic matter in shredded form. Characteristics: Adds organic matter, nutrients, and improves soil structure.

Perlite

Description: Lightweight volcanic glass with high porosity. Characteristics: Lightweight, porous, improves aeration and drainage in soil mixes. Perlite aids with aeration, but has low water retention qualities.

Vermiculite

Description: Mica-based mineral. Characteristics: Improves drainage, retains water and nutrients in soil mixes. Vermiculite aids with aeration and has high water retention qualities

Pumice

Description: Porous volcanic rock. Characteristics: Provides excellent aeration and drainage, lightweight.

Peat

Description: Partially decomposed sphagnum moss. Characteristics: Retains moisture, improves soil structure, slightly acidic to lower pH Very high moisture retention, adds a tiny bit of draingage Also provides moisutre transporation due to capillary effect since it is a fibrous material

Limestone

Description: Mineral used to raise pH in acidic soils. Characteristics: Raises pH, provides calcium and magnesium.

Sphagnum moss

Description: High-quality moss with excellent moisture retention. Characteristics: Excellent moisture retention, aids in aeration and root development. Also provides moisutre transporation due to capillary effect

Coconut coir

Description: Fibrous material from coconut husks. Characteristics: Retains moisture, eco-friendly, provides good aeration.

Bark/wood chips

Description: Bark from fir/pine trees, used in potting mixes. Characteristics: Provides aeration and drainage, commonly used in mixes. High aeration and can hold some moisture

Charcoal

Description: Charred organic matter. Characteristics: Absorbs impurities, improves soil drainage and aeration.

LECA (Lightweight Expanded Clay Aggregate)

Description: Lightweight porous clay pellets. Characteristics: Lightweight, porous, provides aeration and retains moisture.

Coconut chips

Description: Larger coconut husk pieces. Characteristics: Provides aeration, retains moisture, sustainable alternative to bark.

Compost

Description: Decayed organic matter. Characteristics: Adds nutrients, improves soil structure, promotes microbial activity.

Worm castings*

Description: Feces produced by earthworms. Characteristics: Rich in nutrients, enhances soil structure, boosts microbial life.

Lava Rock

Can be used as a top layer for cactii very permeable, good drainage

entry.title: Plant Propagation
entry.content:
Introduction

Plant propagation is the process of producing a new plant from an existing plant.

Sexual propagation is the process of reproduction of plants by seeds. The resulting plant is a genetic combination of each parent plant.

Asexual/vegetative propagation is the process of taking a piece of a (usually mature) plant and growing it into a new plant. The resulting plant is genetically identical to the parent plant and essentially a clone.

Usually when talking about propagation in the context of houseplants, one is referring to the asexual/vegetative variant of propagation and not the sexual variant.

There are a few ways to achieve asexual propagation, explained here.

Asexual propagation

There are 3 ways of propagating houseplants asexually.

  • cuttings (leaf or stem): Chopping off part of a mature plant and rooting it in water or soil
  • division/separation: Splitting a mature plant at the roots to make more plants
  • offsets: Picking ‘pups’, or baby plants, from a mature plant

  • bud cutting

entry.title: Plant Care
entry.content:
Introduction

This guide will explain how to care for plants. In general, plants need 3 things.

  • soil for nutrients
  • water
  • light

Soil

Water

It is not possible to predict how often you should water your plants since it depends on so many factors such as season, humidity, temperature, distance to window, distance to heating, type of pot, maturity of the plant etc.

In general, for most houseplants, don’t water too often. Wait for the soil to dry out before watering. It is better to under-water than to over-water.
